Though it differs from other _____ in several respects, including demeanor—this one is gentle—I have categorized it as a regional form given the vast array of shared qualities.
The power of its jaws is immense—enough to leave teeth marks in iron sheets. Its personality is also extremely vicious.
These Pokémon form schools with others of the same color. The greatest foe of a school of blue _____ is a school of red _____.
Known for their violence, these Pokémon have the most fights with schools of red-striped _____.
Blue-striped _____ used to be a common food source. They apparently have an inoffensive, light flavor.
Some people call it “the thug of the lake.” Whether the differences in color are meaningful is not yet known.
Even _____, which devours everything it can with its huge jaws, is nothing more than food to organisms stronger than itself.
It’s so vicious that it’s called the Thug of the River. Yet _____ is still targeted by predators, such as Dondozo and Bombirdier.
Its temperament is vicious and aggressive. This Pokémon is also full of vitality and can multiply rapidly before anyone notices.
In the past, it often appeared on the dinner table. The meat of red-striped _____ is on the fatty side, and it’s more popular with the youth.
Anglers love the fight this Pokémon puts up on the hook. And there are always more to catch— many people release them into lakes illicitly.
When a school of _____ appears in a lake, everything else disappears, except for Corphish and Crawdaunt. That’s how violent _____ are.
Savage, violent Pokémon, red and blue _____ are always fighting each other over territory.
Red and blue _____ usually do not get along, but sometimes members of one school mingle with the other’s school.
Red- and blue-striped _____ are very violent and always fighting. They are also remarkably tasty.
Red and blue _____ get along so poorly, they’ll start fighting instantly. These Pokémon are very hostile.
